frame.name: Referring_by_name
frame.definition:
<def-root>A <fen>Speaker</fen> uses a particular linguistic form, a <fen>Name</fen> to refer to an <fen>Entity</fen>. The <fen>Entity</fen> often is an interlocutor but may be somebody that the <fen>Speaker</fen> is talking about, or even just a physical object. Note that we include titles such as "Sir" in the <fen>Name</fen> category.
<ex>They corresponded frequently and at length, exchanging intimate letters in which <fex name="spe">he</fex> <t>addressed</t> <fex name="ent">her</fex> <fex name="nam">as Windflower</fex>. </ex>
<ex><fex name="spe">We</fex> always <t>called</t> <fex name="ent">her</fex> <fex name="nam">"my lady,"</fex> from the moment that she was put at the head of our section;</ex>
<ex><fex name="spe">Sharpton</fex> <t>called</t> <fex name="ent">him</fex> <fex name="nam">Obama Baracka</fex> in HIS speech .... of all the people to screw his name up! </ex>
<ex> And then in private <fex name="spe">he</fex> <t>called</t> <fex name="ent">me</fex> <fex name="nam">"Sausage"</fex>, which really pissed me off. </ex> <ex></ex>
<ex> <fex name="spe">Advanced Micro Devices</fex> is going to <t>call</t> <fex name="ent">its next chip</fex> <fex name="nam">the Athlon 4</fex></ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Speaker
FE.definition:
<def-root>The person who uses the <fen>Name</fen> to refer to the <fen>Entity</fen>.
<ex><fex name="spe">The Lord, who was charmed by her beauty,</fex> <t>addressed</t> her as 'than kaadhali!' (My darling) and hence the name.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Entity
FE.definition:
<def-root>The entity that is designated by the <fen>Speaker</fen> with the <fen>Name</fen> used.
<ex>And that's the reason why we <t>called</t> <fex name="ent">him</fex> 'Tom' when his real name was actually John. </ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Name
FE.definition:
<def-root>The linguistic form used by the <fen>Speaker</fen> to refer to the <fen>Entity</fen>.
<ex>A male voice answered the call, and Jones <t>addressed</t> the man as <fex name="nam">"Johnny."</fex></ex></def-root>
